Saving Private Ryan is a cinematic masterpiece that immerses its audience in the brutal and visceral reality of World War II. Directed by Steven Spielberg, the film follows a group of soldiers as they search for a paratrooper, Private James Ryan (Matt Damon), who is the last surviving brother of four soldiers killed in action.

From the opening scene, Spielberg's masterful direction pulls viewers into the chaos and horror of the D-Day invasion. The intense and realistic depiction of the beach landing is one of the most unforgettable moments in cinematic history. The sound design is outstanding, with the roar of gunfire, explosions, and the screams of wounded soldiers all adding to the sense of dread and danger.

The performances in Saving Private Ryan are nothing short of incredible. Tom Hanks delivers a nuanced and emotional portrayal of Captain John Miller, the leader of the search party. The rest of the cast, including Edward Burns, Tom Sizemore, and Barry Pepper, all deliver exceptional performances as well. But it's Matt Damon's portrayal of Private James Ryan that really stands out, with his haunting monologue at the film's climax leaving a lasting impact on the audience.

What makes Saving Private Ryan such a remarkable film is its unflinching portrayal of war. The violence is brutal and unrelenting, and Spielberg doesn't shy away from showing the physical and emotional toll it takes on soldiers. Yet despite the horrors of war, the film also manages to find moments of beauty and humanity, reminding us of the sacrifices made by those who fought for our freedom.

Overall, Saving Private Ryan is a cinematic tour de force that showcases Spielberg's mastery of the craft. The film is an emotional and unforgettable tribute to the brave soldiers who fought and died in World War II, and it remains a timeless classic that should be viewed by all.

"Saving Private Ryan" is a 1998 war/action movie directed by Steven Spielberg, and starring Tom Hanks, Matt Damon, and Tom Sizemore. The film follows a group of soldiers during the Normandy invasion of World War II, as they search for a paratrooper named Private James Ryan who is the last surviving brother of four soldiers.

One of the strongest elements of "Saving Private Ryan" is its depiction of the horrors of war. The film's opening sequence is a tour de force, showing the brutal and chaotic nature of the Normandy invasion with a visceral and unflinching approach. The rest of the film does not shy away from the physical and emotional toll that war takes on soldiers, and the acting by the ensemble cast is exceptional, especially Tom Hanks as Captain John Miller.

The film also features stunning cinematography by Janusz Kaminski, with a desaturated color palette that adds to the film's sense of gritty realism. The use of handheld cameras and quick cuts in the battle scenes also adds to the film's intensity and immediacy.

Steven Spielberg's direction is masterful, skillfully balancing the action and emotion of the film, and creating a sense of tension and urgency throughout. The musical score by John Williams is also excellent, with haunting melodies that capture the film's somber tone.

One potential criticism of the film is its sentimentality. While the film is undoubtedly powerful and moving, some viewers may find the emotional moments to be manipulative or overly melodramatic.

In conclusion, "Saving Private Ryan" is a powerful and visceral war/action movie that is a testament to the sacrifices made by soldiers in World War II. Its exceptional acting, cinematography, and direction make it a classic of the genre, despite some potential criticism of its emotional manipulation. It is a must-watch for any fan of war movies.

One of the most powerful film experiences I've ever had. Steven Spielberg's sobering, emotional, and patriotic WWII film redefined what a war film should be. No romanticizing, no heroics, no good guys or bad guys. What shines through is a kind of humanity rarely witnessed on film. The opening 24-minute D-Day invasion is the most astonishing, ambitious, and meticulously researched and detailed battle sequence ever committed to celluloid. Nothing has ever matched its scope and chaotic grisliness. It perfectly captures the randomness, harrowing devastation, and inhumanity of war. The film isn't just an absorbing story about a rescue mission, it's also a philisophical film about the pointlessness of war. Janus Kaminsky's Oscar-winning cinematography brings a documentary-real look to the events, with bleached-out film stock and gritty, nervy hand-held cameras recreating the look of old newsreel footage of WWII. The acting is superb across the board, with not a single bad performance to be found. Tom Hanks brings down his charisma to play an everyday man caught up in this bloody campaign, who must remain a stoic and strong leader for his men. It still baffles me how this lost the Best Picture Oscar to 'Shakespeare in Love.' Remember that film? No, not many people do. But this is a moving and honorable testament to those men who gave everything in that war, the lives they helped saved, and to Spielberg's legacy as one of the best filmmakers in history. This is the best war film I've ever seen, and one of the greatest American films ever made

I don't think anyone out reading this doesn't have a general idea of what Saving Private Ryan is about, so I'll save the space here, but I'm hoping this review will encourage at least one person who hasn't seen it to do so.  You won't be disappointed.  SPR has long been one of my favorite movies.  Without a doubt the best war movie ever made.  Much has been made about the opening 20 minutes of pure hell where Steve Spielberg subjects the viewer to the horrific experience of those landing on the beaches of Normandy in June 1944, and I would encourage those who are averse to blood or war to put on a brave face and steel yourself through the battle because you will come away with a far greater appreciation of the men who fought so hard to take back what Hitler stole from France and the world.  The high definition realism is terrifying but necessary to understand why the characters quickly become so hardened to their new reality.  The cast is first rate with surprise cameos from familiar names such as Ted Danson, Paul Giamatti, and a youngish Bryan Cranston, but the real awards go to the incredible Tom Hanks and several now familiar stars in their relatively unknown days including Barry Pepper, Vin Diesel, Jeremy Davies, and Edward Burns.  Spielberg hits all the right notes with outstanding battle choreography and effects, pacing that should keep everyone interested, and visual detail and cinematography which leaves you wondering how the beautiful prairies and hillsides of France could have existed so close to the ravages of small villages laid to waste.  I found myself caring for the characters survival as most are well developed and realistic as well as period dialogue as well written as it was read.  SPR isn't without a blunder or two, most notably a scene where the eponymous character played by Matt Damon uncharacteristically balls up and bawls out during the climatic battle, and the final scene was a bit too melodramatic and poorly acted for such an epic movie.  Yet, I remember in 1998 sitting in my theater seat for what seemed like hours (probably 3 or 4 minutes in reality) with a full audience in stunned silence well after the movie ended before finally filing out of what remained a very quiet room - the experience having affected us all.

An elderly veteran visits the Normandy American Cemetery and Memorial with his family. At a tombstone, he falls to his knees with emotion. The scene then shifts to the morning of June 6, 1944, as American soldiers land on Omaha Beach as part of the Normandy Invasion. They suffer heavy losses in assaulting fortified German defensive positions. Captain John H. Miller (Tom Hanks) of the 2nd Ranger Battalion leads a breakout from the beach. Elsewhere on the beach, a dead soldier lies face-down in the bloody surf; his pack is stenciled Ryan, S. In Washington, D.C., at the U.S. War Department, General George Marshall learns that three of the four sons of the Ryan family were killed in action and that the fourth son, Private James Francis Ryan (Matt Damon), is with the 101st Airborne Division somewhere in Normandy. After reading Abraham Lincoln's Bixby letter aloud, Marshall orders Ryan brought home. Three days after D-Day, Miller receives orders to find Ryan and bring him back. He chooses seven men from his company. Sergeant Mike Horvath (Tom Sizemore), Private Richard Reiben (Edward Burns), Private Adrian Caparzo (Vin Diesel), Private Stanley Mellish (Adam Goldberg), Private Daniel Jackson (Barry Pepper), Medic Irwin Wade (Giovanni Ribisi) and Corporal Timothy Upham (Jeremy Davies), an interpreter from headquarters...

Saving Private Ryan received acclaim from critics and audiences; much of the praise went for Spielberg's directing, the realistic battle scenes, the actors' performances, John Williams' score, the cinematography, editing, and screenplay. Rotten Tomatoes  The consensus states "Anchored by another winning performance from Tom Hanks, Steven Spielberg's unflinchingly realistic war film virtually redefines the genre. Many critics associations, such as New York Film Critics Circle and Los Angeles Film Critics Association, chose Saving Private Ryan as Film of the Year. Roger Ebert gave it four stars out of four and called it "a powerful experience". Janet Maslin of The New York Times called it "the finest war movie of our time". Gene Siskel, Ebert's co-host and critic of Chicago Tribune, said that the film "accomplishes something I had been taught was most difficult—making an action-filled anti-war film or, at least, one that doesn't in some way glorify or lie about combat". Writing for TIME, Richard Schickel said that was "a war film that, entirely aware of its genre's conventions, transcends them as it transcends the simplistic moralities that inform its predecessors, to take the high, morally haunting ground". Owen Gleiberman of Entertainment Weekly praised the film, saying that "Spielberg has captured the hair-trigger instability of modern combat." Kenneth Turan of Los Angeles Times praised the film as well, calling it "a powerful and impressive milestone in the realistic depiction of combat, Saving Private Ryan is as much an experience we live through as a film we watch on screen."

Many World War II veterans stated that the film was the most realistic depiction of combat they had ever seen. The film was so realistic that some combat veterans of D-Day and Vietnam left theaters rather than finish watching the opening scene depicting the Normandy invasion. Their visits to posttraumatic stress disorder counselors rose in number after the film's release, and many counselors advised "'more psychologically vulnerable'" veterans to avoid watching it.

Released on July 24, 1998, Saving Private Ryan received acclaim from critics and audiences for its performances, particularly from Hanks, realism, cinematography, score, screenplay, and Spielberg's directing. At the 71st Academy Awards, the film was nominated for 11 Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Actor for Hanks and Best Original Screenplay; it went on to win five for Spielberg's second win for Best Director, Best Film Editing, Best Cinematography, Best Sound, and Best Sound Effects Editing, though the film lost Best Picture to Shakespeare in Love in a controversial upset. The film also won both the Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture – Drama and the Producers Guild of America Award for Best Theatrical Motion Picture, while Spielberg won Golden Globe and Directors Guild of America Award for Best Director. The plot of the film is relatively simple as after the Normandy Invasion seven men are ordered to find Private James Ryan, Matt Damon, and bring him back to America as his mother has lost her three other sons and General George Marshall pities her. The men are led by school teacher John H. Miller, Tom Hanks, whose hand has begun shaking as his power over his men lessens. Fiery Jewish soldier Stanley Mellish, Adam Goldberg, arrogant Southern sniper Daniel Jackson, Barry Pepper, dissenting New Yorker Richard Reiben, Edward Burns, aggressive ally to Miller, Mike Horvath, Tom Sizemore, and Adrian Caparzo, Vin Diesel, are joined by nervous polyglot Timothy Upham, Jeremy Davies, who has never experienced warfare before. Everybody knows the frustrating twist but it doesn't make it any less annoying when it eventually occurs.

The immediacy of the scenes of warfare is shocking as we feel that we are immediately inside the mind of one of the poor soldiers who had to take part in the Normandy landings. Spielberg manages to convey the chaos of war while also allowing us to follow various characters, primarily Miller, as they try their hardest to just survive. The scene also works because it is exciting and interesting to watch but it also gets across the horror of war and makes you absolutely terrified of ever having to be involved in a conflict like that. This is a unique achievement because many films that are supposedly about the horrors of war and how it negatively impacts people end up glorifying war and selling young men on the idea that war is a glorious experience. This scene is impressive and few directors could have directed the scene with as much efficiency and focus as Spielberg did.

Beyond this scene however the film began to lose me as we see the traditional bonding scenes that occur in almost every war film between this very different group of men. The character introduction that Upham receives is almost slapstick and the film doesn't go much deeper than that in digging into his psyche as he serves as the comic relief until he has his moment of redemption at the end of the film. Of course Miller gets a big speech that is undoubtedly the reason that Hanks received an Academy Award nomination but it didn't have the panache of Kirk Douglas' speeches in Paths of Glory (1957). None of the individual character moments were particularly memorable and therefore I felt very little connection to the characters and the sight of various men getting shot was something I became desensitized to as I began to realize that in each battle scene we would lose at least one member of the team. This was not what the filmmakers wanted me to feel and I wish that I cared when Miller died but I didn't and as he tells Ryan to "Earn it" I was not as moved as I would have been in a film that's even slightly more original.

It took me 20 years to decide to watch this, due to my general aversion to Tom Hanks alone or in combination with Steven Spielberg (who, as a director, often veers toward heavy-handedness).  However, this war movie is visceral and gripping enough to overcome the inevitable weaknesses associated with its star and auteur director.  So, yes, we are strongly encouraged to endorse Spielberg's view of the "greatest generation" as uniquely courageous and noble, overcoming horrific obstacles and bonding together as a team, with John Williams' soundtrack sweeping us along and Hanks' central Captain modelling bravery as a do-no-wrong caring and sympathetic but ordinary guy thrust into an impossible situation.  Maybe the war really was like this for some and I offer all of the veterans my thanks and gratitude.  Fortunately, the film isn't all glorification - we do see moments of fear, cowardice, dissent, and cruelty from the Americans that probably better reflect the width of human experience in this sort of crucible.  However, critic Jonathan Rosenbaum argues that Spielberg hasn't offered anything new that past war movies haven't also shown and perhaps that is true.  But this production added a level of grotesque "realism" and "you are there" action/violence that might not have been possible before 1998 - it led to Spielberg's subsequent involvement with WWII based video games and you can see the influence (bi-directional, most likely).  The central plot conceit, that Hanks and his small band (of soon-to-be known young actors) must find Private Ryan (Matt Damon) whose three brothers have already been killed in order to send him home to his grieving mama, allows the characters to reflect on the meaningfulness of their actions and adds another dimension to the film, a focus on the guilt and sadness of those who survived.  Although the film doesn't seem to contain any anti-war messages (perhaps because the moral justifications were so strong in that particular war), thinking about the post-traumatic stress of the former combatants (after seeing the visceral and brutal re-enactments here) is enough to ward anyone off from promoting war as a way to resolve differences.  That said, a case could be made for the film as an army recruitment campaign for those who love action, maybe.

Director Steven Spielberg's war drama epic Saving Private Ryan (1998) remains a moving drama, thrilling war action thriller, and a thoughtful film about morality in times of war. Saving Private Ryan is perhaps Steven Spielberg's most beloved war film ever. He painstakingly recreates D-Day on the beaches of Normandy. It's beautiful and horrifying simultaneously. You're right alongside the soldiers coming off the ships as they desperately run up the beach to capture the German bunker strongholds. It's bloody and brutal with a sense of gritty realism. 

I think Spielberg's direction is by far the best aspect of Saving Private Ryan. It's stream lined as you get to follow a company searching for the last son in a larger family that was all killed in World War II. It's a nice story that reels in audiences everywhere. It's about the value of life, love of family, and the unbearable cost of war. WWII truly feels senseless during the sequences of mortar fire, tank battles, and endless crossfire in a furious hail of bullets. It was necessary to stop the Germans, but we witness the devastating consequences of losing infantry among the territories regained. Saving Private Ryan's greatest accomplishment is making you understand the real value of life. It's worth watching as a testament to those who died during WWII. It touches you in ways you'll find hard to describe. Saving Private Ryan is life affirming as Ryan deeply desires to live a fulfilling life to honor his fallen heroes who got him home.

I found the emotional scenes to be sentimental, but deeply felt from Spielberg's incredible cast. It feels genuine through the sincerity with which Tom Hanks plays the squad's leader. Every battle or encounter is followed by scenes of profound grief, regret, hopelessness, and the need for perseverance and purpose. Writer Robert Rodat hits home with his complex views on morality. You see Germans gun down medics and civilians in evil displays of ruthlessness to the aggressive American forces, frustrated with the senseless violence and aggressions of the German soldiers. 

Every moment is a moral choice, not is killing bad, but rather are the lives lost on this mission worth Ryan's alone?. I feel that of course Ryan's life is not worth more than any other soldier risking their life to defeat Germany, but that it is a profound kindness to send home a mother's last son alive after she has just lost three of her other boys. Ryan can only live his life as best he can, but all the men were valiant in the line of duty. Even the coward Upham ends up killing the German that Hanks spared earlier as some men are too evil to let live. I like that Upham is included as everyone thinks they would be brave in combat, but if many of humanity were themselves in a violent situation, they might just be as cowardly as Upham. Saving Private Ryan is about the nuances of courage as Tom Hanks portrays a simple teacher, who bravely answers the call of duty to lead and inspire despite his fears and doubts. You get all kinds of men herein.

Tom Hanks is fascinating, cool, moving, and brave as stalwart Captain John H. Miller. You see Hanks making choices and feeling his unthinkable burden. Hanks' speech about remembering the 94 men that died under his command is haunting and sympathetic. Saving Private Ryan is up there with Tom Hanks' best roles and greatest films. He should have won Best Actor in all honesty. Tom Sizemore is fierce and loyal as Technical Sergeant Michael Horvath. Edward Burns is intriguing as the increasingly angry and jaded Private Richard Reiben. Matt Damon is at first arrogant and unlikable Private James Francis Ryan, but he earns his stripes as he valiantly defends the bridge under fire.

Barry Pepper should have gotten a Best Supporting Actor as the skilled and faithful sniper Private Daniel Jackson. His sniping sequences are breathtaking as he prays to God for strength as he rapidly reloads and blows away Nazis with extreme precision. Pepper is gripping like few actors ever get to be on the silver screen. Adam Goldberg is hilarious and devastating as the Jewish soldier Private Stanley Mellish. Goldberg finds the balance of Mellish's rage and sorrow at the horrors the German Nazis have unleased upon his people. Vin Diesel got me pretty upset to see what happens to him just because his character Private Adrian Caparzo wants to save a child. Giovanni Ribisi is haunting as he witnesses brutal wounds and begs for his mother as T-Medic Irwin Wade.

Ted Danson has a great cameo as Captain Fred Hamill. Jeremy Davies is fantastic as the well meaning interpreter and cowardly ammo holder Corporal Timothy Upham. The entirety of Saving Private Ryan you can see how Upham was not made for war and fails in his responsibility to protect his fellow allies. Paul Giamatti is funny and serious as the helpful Sergeant William Hill. Nathan Fillion has a funny scene as Minnesota Ryan. Leland Orser is immediately mesmerizing as the worn down Lieutenant DeWindt. Bryan Cranston has a nice cameo as War Department Colonel.

Michael Kahn's editing takes you around a war torn France and all over the battlefield with slick cuts. 169 minutes passes by quickly due to Kahn's fast pace and sterling ability to know when to show a close-up of a character's face for deeper emotional empathy. 

Cinematographer Janusz Kamiński's wide shots for all the battle sequences are glorious like his interesting framing for each man's thinking about his family, values, or losses. I love how up close and personal his shots get with shaking camera work like you're a soldier right beside Spielberg's heroes. All the sets are realistic, booming sounds echo, and gore effects appear real for Saving Private Ryan's stunning technical achievements.

Composer John Williams provides a lovely and eerie score that rises with good intentions and forlorn feelings. Williams' melodies are simply stunning. Even the music is masterful in Saving Private Ryan.

Overall, Saving Private Ryan is still one of the must see war films in cinema history. You'll be stunned at the scope of the D-Day invasion and humbled at Hanks' acting and empathy. Give it a watch.

Steven Spielberg directed this powerful, realistic re-creation of WWII's D-day invasion and the immediate aftermath. The story opens with a prologue in which a veteran brings his family to the American cemetery at Normandy, and a flashback then joins Capt. So I've never been a fan of movies made pre-2000's. It's not that I don't want to be, but I just haven't enjoyed older styles of filmmaking. However, being a lover of war films, I've been told repeatedly that I have to watch "Saving Private Ryan". Now being in college and having access to an on campus library where I can check out movies, I decided it was finally time. So, I checked out "Saving Private Ryan" and to my added surprise, I had a ton of fun with this film. 

Let's start out by saying that this is an all-star cast. A lot of guys from top to bottom have all made strong careers for themselves to date. A lot of them put up great performances, to the point where it's hard to point out any individual performance other than Tom Hanks. Tom Hanks really led the cast here and puts up an amazing performance like always. I love seeing him, as there haven't been a ton of films with him lately, so it's nice to see an older movie where he originally starred. I think even if you're not interested in this film, you should give it a chance based on the cast alone. 

For a film made nearly two decades ago, it still holds up really well. Everything from the effects, set design, acting, etc, all hold up really well. This is honestly a film that could've been made today, just with a dated resolution. I think a lot of things were really strong, especially the fact that this film was a bit hard to watch at times. It goes with the strong message that war is ugly and nothing about it is pretty. The situation they're put in and no matter how many medals or awards you receive, nothing about the situation is fun. You're watching people die and limbs being blown off, and none of it is glorified. It's all supported with a fantastic score and it all came together to give us a really complete war film.

In the end, I thoroughly enjoyed this film and it was actually one of the best war films I've ever seen. Chalk that up as a win for 90s movies.
Simply, one of the best films ever made.

Lauded by many to be the Greatest War Film Ever, well it just might be. At least in my books, it's the most complete war movie ever, it covers all aspect of a war, from the glory to the regret. It got realistic action ranging from battalion battle sequences to small squad action. The opening sequence was the most intense and gory battle scene I have come across. Got a human story to tell, the on-road adventure of a squad shows us all the faces of war, got camaraderie, humor, resentment, bravery, and cowardice. In the end not sure if it's an anti-war movie or a celebration of war.
